prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling a friend he is being creepy and pathetic following a breakup?
My friend was with this girl for about eight months. He is 22.

While he was with her, he would go on and on about how she was "the one" and how they were going to get married, etc. 

She recently broke up with him because he was moving way too fast in the relationship and he needs time to work on himself and deal with his anxiety.

He completely lost it after this. We ended up having to call 911 and have him taken to the hospital because he was calling her and us threatening harm on himself. 

He constantly calls her asking why she can't take him back, and he told us that if she's in the city, he might go to her place and "ask her in person". 

Well, me and my friends all took turns spending time with him after the hospital visit and on my turn I just lost it after hearing for the fifth time how he was going to "get her back."

I told him he was being creepy and pathetic and that she has made it abundantly clear that she doesn't want to get back together with him and he needs to stop all this behavior. 

He got really pissed and kicked me out of his apartment.

My friends told me that I probably could have done it in a nicer way but that they agree with me.

So AITA for telling him all that?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the person (AITA) is in the wrong for telling their friend he's being creepy and pathetic after a breakup. 

First, the friend was in a relationship that ended because he was moving too fast and had anxiety. After the breakup, he's acting out—calling the ex, threatening self-harm, planning to confront her. The author intervened, told him he's being creepy and to stop, which led to a fight.

The key points here are the friend's behavior post-breakup. He's not just sad; he's engaging in behaviors that could be considered stalking or harassment. The author is concerned about safety, both of the ex and their friend. The author's friends agree with them, though they think a nicer approach might have worked.

Now, is the author in the wrong? The friend's actions are definitely problematic. The author is trying to prevent further harm. Even if the delivery was harsh, the message is valid. The friend needs to stop his behavior. The author's intent was to help, not to belittle. The friend's reaction was anger, but that doesn't mean the author was wrong. The alternative would be to stay silent, which could lead to worse consequences. So the author isn't in the wrong. Answer B.
